ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot about DNA and lab methods.

I learned some lab skills that I hadn't done before, like kinetic assays, agar assays, and transformations. I also had never used protein modeling software like Pymol, which I think will be very useful later in my STEM career here.

-you learn and understand well many basic biochem techniques
-altho I already knew most techniques I feel I got a better understanding 
-also learn to use pymol
I learned so much. All of the experiments we did were based on skills necessary for biochemical research.
Biochemistry techniques and methods. The course is structured as a semester-long project.

I learned how to use PyMOL, protein purification through nickel column chromatography, photospectrometer programming, good pipetting technique, how to make an SDS-PAGE gel, a lot about S. nuclease / DHFR / triose phosphate isomerase enzymes, and nuclease activity agar assays. I also learned a lot about the history of DNA / RNA through the various informative documentaries that we watched, as well as some more modern tools like Illumina sequencing / ChatGPT through the midterm presentations. (There are also many other lab techniques covered in the course, but I already had experience with those.)
Biochemistry laboratory skills
I learned multiple wet-lab techniques and procedures that will definitely help me in the future as a pre-med and biology student.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Since this lab took all four hours allotted every week it was a bit exhausting.

Strengths: experiments are useful skills for general lab work, assignments allowed us to practice data analysis skills/how to think critically about findings
Weaknesses: I don't think we ever left lab before 5:30/5:45pm and often it felt like there was a lot of wasted time during those 4 hours (as in, rearranging the structure of some days would've allowed us to not be there the entire time when it wasn't necessary); lab notebook assignments felt like busywork because we used the printed manuals for protocols during class; sometimes did't have enough guidance on the assignments in the second half of the semester so we wasted a lot of time trying to figure it out, even with the help of the TAs

-packets are very well written and explanations make a lot of sense. Physics lab should take notes
-year long process thats connected is very satisfying
-good classroom environment
-sometimes we do things just to take up the full 4 hours. Id suggest to design so that if people finish early they can leave. I dont think watching some of the documentaries should be mandatory. Altho theyre cool, on a busy week it feels not optimal
Dr. Pawashe and the TFs were amazing. No complaints.

Strengths: You learn a lot of useful lab techniques 
Weaknesses: You are always in lab for the full time even if you finish early
Strengths: Prof. Pawashe and the teaching team are amazing

Strengths: The course is excellently organized and a lot of time, care, and dedication was clearly put into its pedagogy. For scheduling conflicts, the teaching staff are highly accommodating. Aruna and the teaching staff are always there extra early, setting up the labs and open to student questions. I love the amount of hands-on work in this course; it truly gives exposure to a breadth of techniques. It is a rarity to find a STEM course that is genuinely fun and enjoyable all the way through; of the 41 courses I've taken at Yale, this would undoubtedly rank in the top 3. Finally, the sense of community fostered in this course is underrated and I've made many friends. In particular, I thought that having group discussions for triplets of conceptual questions was quite innovative, if not in concept then in its implementation, which fostered engagement.

Weaknesses: The quizzes were somewhat difficult, but I think that forces you to learn more.
Didnt always utilize time most effectively but was appropriately challenging and also an overall enjoyable course
Very organized, content increases towards the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if they don't have a lot of experience with lab skills like pipetting, loading gels, PCRs etc because they can learn a lot of that. Overall I think the content was important and I learned a lot, but some of the assignments did not feel very enlightening, and the project we conducted throughout the term was nearly the same as the Lim and Sauer paper that it was based on, so the findings just felt a bit redundant
Yes! Its a great lab thats well organized and is satisfying
Yes. Great for Pre-Med!
Yes
This is most likely a prerequisite, but its not too much work and taught well.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in performing biochemistry research. It provides a solid foundation from which you can learn the specialized skills for a particular research lab. Every now and then, I'll remember a useful tidbit from this course while in the lab!
Yes, it was an enjoyable course
I would definitely recommend this course to other students! Not only was Professor Aruna amazing, but the lectures were taught in a very engaging, informative, and exciting way.
